description: The photographer, from New York, looks for abandoned stations and tunnels, but has had near death experiences as trains come whizzing past.
title: Urban explorer known as Dark Cyanide risks his life photographing New York
title_page: Urban explorer known as Dark Cyanide risks his life photographing New York | Daily Mail Online
text:
He has been caught by workers and the authorities many times despite hiding when trains come speeding past
A daring urban explorer has risked his life in order to snap a stunning series images of New York's subway tracks.
At the dead of night, the photographer - known only to his Instagram followers as Dark Cyanide - heads out to look for hidden gems, like abandoned stations, provisions and tunnels.
His intriguing images feature vibrant streaks, graffiti, and tight framing - and by adding individuals to some to some of shots, he is also able to depict the incredible scale of some of the tunnels.
The photographer, 19, admitted what he and his friends do is highly dangerous, illegal, and he does not recommend others attempt to explore such tunnels.
As well as roaming New York, Dark Cyanide has also shot subway tunnels in Boston and Los Angeles. On his expeditions, the explorer travels with experienced tunnel runners - usually in groups of between three and five people.
The more people present the more difficult it is to hide when the train come speeding past.
Dark Cyanide revealed he has had a number of 'near death experiences' and has been caught by workers and the authorities on a number of occasions.
The explorer, from New York, said: 'People look at tunnels as dark portals with nothing in between - there's so much more in the darkness outside of the train.
'People love underground shots because they can never see it through the darkness and speed of the train going through the tunnels.
'I like to capture the old graffiti, structure of the tunnel, the way the tracks curve and switch. I aim to create an artistic vision of the tunnel.'
An unnamed subway track in New York: Dark Cyanide pictures graffiti like the 'We Own The Night' slogan pictured here
A tunnel runner is pictured in the bowels of the New York subway system
Which way now? Two explorers check out the subway tracks in Los Angeles
Masked: The explorers know they face prosecution if they are caught so cover their faces in pictures on subway trains or underground.
Dark Cyanide has had a number of near death experiences as trains come rushing through the tunnels
Round the bend: 'People love underground shots because they can never see it through the darkness and speed of the train going through the tunnels.'
The explorer, from New York, said: 'People look at tunnels as dark portals with nothing in between - there's so much more in the darkness outside of the train.'
